awd_titl_txt: STEM Pathways and Research Alliances: New Mexico Alliance for Minority Participation
awd_abstract_narration:
The New Mexico Alliance for Minority Participation (NM AMP), part of the nation-wide Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation, is a mature Alliance of seven public universities and seven public 2-year colleges. Collaborators include industry partners; two National Science Foundation (NSF) Engineering Research Center (ERC) projects; the NSF-funded New Mexico EPSCoR project; the New Mexico Math, Engineering, Science Achievement program (New Mexico MESA, Inc.); and the Arizona-based LSAMP, the Western Alliance to Expand Student Opportunities (WAESO). The NMAMP provides support services and funding opportunities for Under Represented Minority (URM) students pursuing careers in STEM fields in the state of New Mexico. In Phase VI of the program, which will be years 26 through 30 of the program, NM AMP will include a social science/educational research component will seek to better understand the roles and interactions of students and faculty mentors in the development of scientists and engineers, and to better inform the design, execution, and assessment of such programs. Over the lifetime of NM AMP, the number of STEM B.S. degrees awarded annually to URMs in New Mexico has increased from 253 in 1992-93 to 858 in 2015-16. During the same time period, the percentage of B.S. STEM degrees awarded to URM students increased from 24% to 48%.

Phase VI on NM AMP will accomplish the following: 1) Sustain proven strategies and activities, 2) Implement enhancements to further improve students' educational experiences and prepare them for the STEM workforce and/or graduate studies; 3) Contribute to the development of institutional contexts that support URM student achievement through an innovative new faculty development workshop, and 4) Conduct social science research to further understand and disseminate findings on the challenges for URM students in STEM. The NM AMP Pathway supports URM students at partnering two- and four-year institutions and provides them with multiple opportunities to explore STEM programs and careers, engage in undergraduate research, and participate in additional programs and opportunities that support early career exploration, the development of STEM identity, and foster self-efficacy and the self-directed pursuit of academic and career goals. The Pathway rejects deficit-based thinking that assumes students lack either qualities or abilities for achievement and, instead, embraces a strengths-based approach that recognizes the unique contributions and interests of individual students and provides them with guidance and experiences that enable each student to achieve his or her full potential. Evidence-based activities along the Pathway include undergraduate research experiences (domestic and international), professional development events, and skills-building workshops.  The alliance will also support changes in institutional climate to increase learning and retention of URM students in STEM.  New activities and priorities include the following: 1) Implement a rigorous, mixed methods social science research project focused on better understanding the factors that shape students' scientific identity and STEM retention, including dissemination of outcomes in quick turnaround mini-studies and peer-review articles; 2) Enhance student support activities with the addition of entry level stipends that provide opportunities for students to explore research options early in their college careers, a Professional Development Webinar Series, and an E-Portfolio option; and 3) Pilot a new Context Diversity Faculty Development Workshop to promote effective change in learning environments to better support URM student achievement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
New Mexico Alliance for Minority Participation (NM AMP) is a partnership representing 13 of the New Mexico's public two- and four-year colleges and universities. With the aim of significantly impacting retention and persistence of STEM underrepresented minority students, our goals are  to 1) increase the numbers of underrepresented students who earn the B.S. degree and encourage progression to graduate school in STEM and 2) raise the number of students who transfer from 2-year to 4-year institutions in the state. NM AMP focuses on research-related and transfer-related programs, activities, and events.

With a strong contribution from NM AMP, collaborations with many statewide STEM programs have resulted in significant increases in the number and percentage of B.S. STEM degrees earned by underrepresented students in New Mexico. The number of underrepresented minority students who have earned the B.S. degree in STEM has increased  from 253 (24%) in 1992-93, when NM AMP was established,  to 947 (51%) in 2018-19 when the current reporting period (2018-2024) for the Continuing Grant started. The latest data shows that 951 (59%) of underrepresented minority students earned B.S. degrees in STEM  in 2022-23. 

With the focus on research-related and transfer-related programs, NM AMP gives specific attention to program activities that are designed to assist with retention and progression to the university and to the  B.S. degree in STEM with engaging programs that help students with transfer of knowledge to their coursework, internships, and future professional lives. With the use and replication of Best Practices, programs have been developed to scaffold  instructional methods and gradually remove guidance and support as students learn and become more competent  (i.e. STEM PREP, an introduction to research program, to the Undergraduate Research Scholars Program, in which students participate as Research Assistants with faculty mentors).

The programs, activities and events of NM AMP advance knowledge and broaden understanding within the STEM disciplines by establishing and disseminating new and adapted models for nurturing student success and persistence.

Because of the strong evidence from the reserarch literature as well as from evaluation of the NM program itself, that undergraduate research experiences and academic and professional socialization activities help cultivate scientific identify and facilitate STEM persistence for underrerpesented minority students (Thiry, et al, 2012), the NSF-mandated research study has helped us understand the mechanisms underlying the success of broadening participation for programs, such as NM AMP. 

To address the intellectual merit of the project, the social science research study was undertaken with the aims of 1) developing and testing a comprehensive model of how college experiences shape scientific identity development and STEM educational outcomes for underrepresented minority students; and 2) contributing to an understanding of the role of faculty in shaping student’s STEM trajectories. The researchers used a mixed methods approach that included a longitudinal quantitative survey administered to approximately 4000 students to explore factors associated with STEM outcomes; qualitative student interviews to elucidate how specific interactions and experiences contribute to scientific identity formation; and faculty interviews to identify how various institutional cultures, practices, and perceptions may contribute to differential access to STEM opportunities. This research has already begun to contribute to knowledge and understanding of student success by establishing and disseminating new and adapted models that support the academic and professional development of URM students in STEM.  Analysis of this data is still ongoing, but to date, findings have been disseminated through two publications (https://peer.asee.org/37917; https://peer.asee.org/35663) and 17 academic conference presentations. Important contributions of the research study include findings confirming the importance of supporting programs that cultivate STEM identity, encourage diverse teaching approaches, and provide access to various forms of STEM capital (e.g. economic, social and informational resources) and also guidance on how students can mobilize those resources to persist and thrive in STEM.

NM AMP contributes to the improved retention, graduation, and professional success of participating underrepresented STEM students. Professional development training and research experiences help students make more knowledgeable decisions about their future careers. By training students to think critically by participating in experiences that engage and promote mindful intellectual growth, their perspectives are broadened. Teaching and research provided by NM AMP broadens the research infrastructure of the institution. NM AMP has a long, rich history of success in effective changes in STEM education. Actively engaging undergraduates in research that is interesting and relevant helps students persist, gain confidence, and self-efficacy, which transfers to academic success and wise professional decisions. Program evaluation findings indicate that student interventions developed by NM AMP have positively impacted institutional culture and practices that promote STEM student success. Faculty development workshops NM AMP has held further promote improvements in learning environments. Project outcomes, including evidence-based outcomes of our social science research activities and summative evaluation data, have been disseminated broadly. These lessons learned  share promising directions for STEM education and student achievement, and encourage replication of best practices.
